data.title: A Woman's Revenge (2012)
data.meta_description: Roberto is one of those men to whom simulation has become the greatest art. He is an unmoved, inscrutable, mysterious man. But the truth is that Robert feels an intimate, deep tedium. The boredom of those who have already exhausted all the pleasures of life. The only thing still surprising him is the fact that nothing surprises him anymore. One evening he has an overwhelming encounter with a woman. For his own bewilderment, he discovers the sublime horrors in which the woman has sank.
data.text:
Nearly 100 years after sound was introduced. The equilibrium between image and language has finally been reached: classicism perfected.

Time hath its order regularly known,

Not so the world, which so confused doth roll,

That God thereof would all forgetful seem:

Nature, opinions, use, events, the whole

Combine to make us feel the life we own

Is really nothing but a dream.

"It is as when we listen to stories in our childhood; we see all that we hear. When someone tells us a story, we see it immediately. If the film has a voice-over narration, the voice, the narration, adds an additional image that comes from what is being heard to what is being seen on the screen. This,…

Cinema that settles into the veins, bores into the bones, softening its silky reds against the back of the eyelids. The sort of story-telling that gifts the glimmer of distant eyes, a gaze that speaks of a thousand unspoken words, a hundred unfelt emotions... one single shard of unforgettable trauma.

Roberto is suave, worldly, but adrift in aristocratic malaise. One evening, he is seduced by a prostitute, lured in by her air of mystery. Already he can sense something. A break in the relentless routine, something that teasingly lifts the veil of his boredom. For this encounter will prove to be like none other: it is the chance meeting of a lifetime. And, truly, they are both ghosts, for she…

A Woman’s Revenge, is a 19th century melodrama richly infused in Rita Azevedo Gomes’ ethereal style of languorous, dreamy storytelling. This one begins as if from a book, with a third person narrator easing us into the tale, before the story is picked up by an incidental character who continues the telling direct to audience, as if on the stage. And then the telling quickly passes again, this time slipping into the thoughts of Roberto, a world weary dandy and aristocratic playboy, now bored and dulled by the repetitions of excess. Bored that is, until his interest is piqued by a prostitute, who reminds him of someone he can’t quite place. She seduces him and now he begins to remember…
